title: What are the traditional purification days and beliefs of Pythagorean philosophy?
first_phrase: In the preceding text, the author translates and comments on fragments of Pythagorean writings that touch on issues of silence, purification, intelligence and life after death. In the last 200 tokens, he raises questions about the nature and purpose of (High) Magic. The author discusses the meaning and possible ambiguity of an enigmatic verse about the 'Intelligence' and discusses whether the quests for spiritual progress and truth need to be pursued and achieved in this life or whether they extend beyond it.

last_phrase: In conclusion, the ambiguity between the personal intelligence, supreme intelligence, and various forms of intelligences is intentional in the pursuit of an ideal unity. Cicero's passages reinforce the belief that true life is beyond the bounds of the physical body. These esoteric concepts are further elucidated through Macrobius' interpretation, providing a deeper understanding of ancient wisdom. Ultimately, this pursuit of knowledge serves as the active purpose of High Magic, which can be achieved during life or after death.
